image.altText: NT parliament building

props.synopsis: New bail laws are set to be passed during an urgent sitting of NT parliament, a week after the fatal stabbing of a Darwin supermarket owner.

title.children: NT parliament urgently reconvenes to pass bail laws after fatal shop stabbing

image.altText: A man standing inside a room and holding out a machete to the camera.

props.synopsis: The 18-year-old charged with murder over the death of Darwin supermarket owner Linford Feick has faced court for the first time since the fatal stabbing.

title.children: Phillip Randel Maurice Parry faces court charged with murder of Darwin grocer

image.altText: Shuqin Li

props.synopsis: Members of Darwin's Chinese community are calling for federal Labor and the Coalition to reconsider their election promises to take back the lease of the Darwin Port.

title.children: Chinese community urges rethink on Labor, Coalition's Darwin Port plans

image.altText: The facade of a new police station in Darwin's northern suburbs

props.synopsis: The unstaffed Nightcliff Police Station stands opposite to where 71-year-old supermarket owner Linford Feick was fatally stabbed last week.

title.children: Concerns over $12m 'white elephant' police station opposite fatal stabbing site

image.altText: A digital illustration of a large housing development in the rural area, beside a lake.

props.synopsis: The company behind a controversial planned housing development in Darwin's rural area has relaunched its bid, years after it was rejected under a different name.

title.children: Proposal for 4,000 new Darwin homes relaunched years after rejection

image.altText: A man stands with his arms crossed in front of a house next to an empty lot.

props.synopsis: The major parties have decided on a solution to Australia's housing crisis: build more homes. But some of the country's newest suburbs suggest it's not as straightforward as it seems.

title.children: 'What I feel is left out': The growing pains of Australia's newest suburbs

image.altText: Two men in suits shake hands in front of flags of Australia and China.

props.synopsis: While the diplomatic tone has softened between Australia and China, the tensions between the two countries have not disappeared, and could still shape how some Australians vote on Saturday.

title.children: China takes back seat in vote, though risks could still shape policy

image.altText: Anthony Albanese holds hands with his fiancee as they smile and walk into a rally.

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese says he would be "happy" to ban texts from political parties but he is not sure if it will fit in with "other legal requirements". Follow live.

title.children: PM says fiancee on receiving end of Palmer's 'vanity exercise' texts

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: We're standing by for a Peter Dutton press conference
PM says he'd be happy to ban election texts
PM denies Penny Wong suggested a resurrected Voice was inevitable

image.altText: People handing out A4 sheets of paper to a woman carrying a shopping bag on a street.

props.synopsis: Working from home is key for these voters in one of Australia's fastest-growing areas but as the election draws near many people here don't think any Labor or Coalition policy will help them much.

title.children: 'Disconnect' with major parties a major problem for this rapidly growing area

image.altText: Purple sign reads "voting centre"

props.synopsis: Advance Australia is one of several relatively new groups aiming to replicate the success of activists on the left, but confronts a more fragmented right.

title.children: A constellation of conservative groups has altered the campaign landscape

image.altText: a composite image of two women

props.synopsis: Brooke Bellamy rejects claims by popular Australian cook Nagi Maehashi that two recipes in the cookbook Bake with Brooki are copied.

title.children: Brooki Bakehouse rejects plagiarism claims from RecipeTin Eats founder

image.altText: Donald Trump holds a large poster board listing reciprocal tariffs for each country.

props.synopsis: Markets are set for another day of moderate gains, and the US has posted a record trade deficit for March ahead of the imposition of Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs in April. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Shares keep rising as US sees record trade deficit

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ASX opens modestly higher, Westpac shrugs off hedging losses
Almost no private rental properties affordable for welfare recipients
Coles' revenue rises as shoppers look for promos

image.altText: Donald Trump speaks while standing outside.

props.synopsis: US President Donald Trump acknowledges Australia's efforts to talk to him about trade and says he intends to speak to the Australian prime minister about the issue.

title.children: PM shrugs off Trump's 'throwaway comment' on Australia's efforts to call

image.altText: A woman in a white Ao Dai salutes while holding a Vietnamese flag near a statue of Ho Chi Minh.

props.synopsis: Massive parades and events are being rehearsed as Vietnam prepares to mark the 50th anniversary of the fall of Saigon, which was also the beginning of one of Australia's largest migrations.

title.children: 'I still carry a bit of guilt': The Vietnam War's half-century of pain

image.altText: A man with his lips pursed looking sideways

props.synopsis: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney's Liberals will form government with a minority, according to Canadian public broadcaster CBC.

title.children: Mark Carney's Liberals fall short of majority in Canadian election

image.altText: Jan Massey smiles, wearing a neck scarf

props.synopsis: Dozens of HESTA super fund members told ABC News they weren't aware of the planned outage, despite HESTA announcing the seven-week freeze back in February.

title.children: Super fund members caught out without access in seven-week freeze

image.altText: A smiling, dark-haired young woman in flared jeans stands in bare feet on a house veranda.

props.synopsis: Young people in some of Australia's most expensive regional towns are disappointed with both major parties, as experts warn their policies are likely to push house prices up even further.

title.children: 'Angry' young voters in most expensive towns reject housing policies

image.altText: Pedestrians shelter from rain under umbrellas in a wet city.

props.synopsis: A run of showery and stormy days is soaking Australia's east coast, while a record drought across South Australia and Victoria continues to intensify.

title.children: East coast drenching set to continue as SA, Vic struggle through big dry

image.altText: In this photo illustration a Amazon logo seen displayed on a smartphone.

props.synopsis: US President Donald Trump labels a reported plan by online retailer Amazon to display the cost of US tariffs on its products as a "hostile and political act".

title.children: Trump slams Amazon proposal to show cost of tariffs on goods

image.altText: A pair of hands typing on a laptop. A red Griffith sign in the background.

props.synopsis: A man wanted for allegedly hacking Griffith University in 2013 left the country using a different identity and was able to re-enter Australia while a warrant for his arrest was active, court documents allege.

title.children: Wanted hacker left country with different ID after police raid, court documents allege

image.altText: Less Kiss smiles ahead of a 2025 Super Rugby Pacific match.

props.synopsis: Les Kiss will be the next Wallabies coach, but not until next year after Joe Schmidt agreed to extend his tenure.

title.children: Kiss to succeed Schmidt as Wallabies coach in 2026

image.altText: George Hewett is hugged by Patrick Cripps and teammates

props.synopsis: Carlton strings together three straight victories to get back into the finals mix led by a player who many consider to be an afterthought outside the club. Here's what we learned from round seven of the AFL season.

title.children: Carlton's season is alive again, and an unheralded hero has resuscitated it

image.altText: A woman with a black shirt and glasses looks at the camera in a cafe.

props.synopsis: With the world's spotlight on tiny Morwell this week, some struggling businesses are hoping a small influx of media for the mushroom trial will bring a silver lining to an event that has otherwise cast a dark cloud over the town.

title.children: What's it like in the town hosting the triple-murder mushroom trial?

image.altText: Two people, Darcy and Caitlin, sit outside a home with Caitlin holding a mug.

props.synopsis: Not a single property or room is affordable for people on Jobseeker, Youth Allowance or the Disability Support Pension in Western Australia, an Anglicare report finds.

title.children: WA rental crisis deepens amid 'catastrophic' price hikes, report finds

image.altText: A Palestinian medic wearing his paramedic uniform and looking at the camera for an official work portrait.

props.synopsis: The Palestinian Red Crescent Society paramedic was detained a month ago when Israeli forces opened fired on a convoy of ambulances he was travelling with.

title.children: IDF releases Palestinian medic month after deadly attack on ambulances

image.altText: Woman with short hair smiles with mouth closed

props.synopsis: The future of salmon farming in Tasmania's Macquarie Harbour remains under "active" assessment by the federal government, despite the passing of legislation designed to nullify the issue.

title.children: Despite new laws, salmon farming assessment still 'active' for Macquarie Harbour

image.altText: A mural of two sheep painted on a brick wall.

props.synopsis: The three-way contest for Australia's newest electorate, the semi-rural seat of Bullwinkel, is shaping up as one of the most fiercely fought battles.

title.children: Urban fringe collides with farming in battle for Australia's newest federal seat

image.altText: Samreen takes a selfie with a scenic backdrop

props.synopsis: As debate around international student numbers intensifies, a report reveals they experience poorer mental health than their domestic counterparts.

title.children: It's a $51bn industry, but who’s looking out for Australia's international students?

image.altText: An in-flight picture of an airliner over a beach, the plane in purple and white livery showing the word "Bonza".

props.synopsis: Bonza promised to shake up the aviation industry by offering cheap flights to destinations ignored by the bigger airlines. But it did not take long for the cracks to appear.

title.children: It's one year since Bonza went bust. Will it ever be replaced?

image.altText: A man with a brunette mullet in a black shirt smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: When Brett Blake was 17, he was charged with inciting a riot, disorderly conduct and assaulting a public officer. His MICF Most Outstanding Show-nominated stand-up hour calls for second chances.

title.children: This comedian almost went to jail at 17. His show is about second chances

image.altText: Flames come out of a long two-storey burning building at night.

props.synopsis: Firefighters rescue two people from a burning hostel in Bowen in north Queensland, and police are investigating the cause of the blaze.

title.children: Two rescued from burning north Queensland backpackers' hostel

image.altText: A young woman wearing a grey suit with a white undershirt stands outside court with sunglasses

props.synopsis: Police Inspector Amy Scott, who fatally shot Joel Cauchi the day of his attack at the Westfield Bondi Junction Shopping Centre last year, has described her encounter on the second day of the coronial inquest.

title.children: Officer who shot Bondi Junction stabber thought she was 'probably going to die'

image.altText: Fingal Bay

props.synopsis: The Liberals and the Nationals are both eyeing off working class seats that were once unquestionably Labor territory, but has the Coalition's nuclear policy blown wind farms out of the water as an issue for voters?

title.children: It's the energy election everywhere, but nowhere quite like the Hunter

image.altText: A red sold sticker across a for sale sign outside a house with a large front yard on a sunny day

props.synopsis: The major parties are working hard to keep Australian house prices at record highs, but a moderate fall in values may be just what Australia's economy needs in the long-term.

title.children: Why house prices can, and need to, fall

image.altText: Portrait of black woman talking to phone virtual assistant

props.synopsis: Experts say systems relying on artificial intelligence can make your life easier. Here’s what you may want to consider if you’re a beginner.

title.children: Why you should consider using AI if you've been avoiding it
